message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. Acting out is a defense mechanism in which the individual deals with emotional conflict or stress by engaging in impulsive or unacceptable behavior. In this case, the patient's behavior of skipping classes, bullying, and smoking cigarettes can be seen as a manifestation of his emotional turmoil after his father's departure and his mother's infidelity. Projection involves attributing one's own unacceptable thoughts or feelings onto others, passive aggression involves indirect resistance to authority or demands, and regression involves reverting to an earlier stage of emotional development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. Acting out is a defense mechanism in which a person expresses their inner emotional conflicts through their external behavior. The patient's behavior of skipping classes, bullying, and smoking cigarettes can be seen as an expression of his emotional turmoil caused by his parents' marital problems. Projection involves attributing one's own unacceptable impulses or feelings onto others, passive aggression involves expressing aggression in a passive way, and regression involves reverting to an earlier stage of development. These defense mechanisms do not fully explain the patient's behavior.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. Acting out is a defense mechanism in which an individual responds to stress by engaging in impulsive or destructive behavior. The patient's behavior of skipping classes, bullying, aggression, and smoking cigarettes is consistent with acting out as a defense mechanism.

We refer to Psychology Today articles for help. Acting out is defined as expressing negative feelings and impulses through actions rather than through communication or self-reflection. The patient's behavior, such as skipping classes, bullying, and smoking, can be seen as acting out as a result of his emotional distress surrounding his parents' marital issues. Projection involves attributing one's own unacceptable feelings and thoughts to others. Passive aggression involves expressing anger indirectly, such as through intentional inefficiency or stubbornness. Regression involves reverting to behaviors associated with an earlier stage of development. None of these defense mechanisms fit the patient's behavior as described in the scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. Acting out is defined as expressing one's emotional conflicts or impulses through physically or verbally inappropriate behavior. The patient's behavior of skipping classes, bullying, and smoking cigarettes can be seen as an expression of his emotional conflict and distress related to his family situation. Projection involves attributing one's own unacceptable thoughts or impulses to others, while passive aggression involves expressing aggression in a subtle or indirect manner. Regression refers to reverting to an earlier stage of development. None of these defense mechanisms adequately describe the patient's behavior.

We refer to a Psychology Today article for help. Acting out is defined as "behaving in a way that is inappropriate for the situation or breaking rules in a way that is conspicuous." The patient's behavior of skipping classes, bullying, aggressive behavior, and smoking cigarettes are all examples of acting out in response to the stress of his parents' marital problems. Projection involves attributing one's own feelings or desires to someone else, passive aggression involves expressing aggression in an indirect manner, and regression involves reverting to behaviors associated with an earlier stage of development. None of these defense mechanisms accurately describe the patient's behavior.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. Acting out is the most appropriate defense mechanism that describes the change in behavior. The patient is expressing his feelings through actions rather than addressing them verbally. Projection involves attributing one's own unacceptable feelings or thoughts to others. Passive aggression involves expressing aggression in an indirect way. Regression involves reverting back to an earlier stage of development. None of these defense mechanisms fit the description of the patient's behavior.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acting out involves expressing negative feelings through actions rather than words or introspection. The patient's behavior, including skipping classes, bullying, and smoking, are examples of acting out. The other options, projection, passive aggression, and regression, do not fully capture the patient's behavior. Projection involves attributing one's own unacceptable feelings to others, passive aggression involves expressing aggression indirectly, and regression involves reverting to earlier developmental stages to cope with stress.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. Acting out is when an individual uses physical or verbal actions to express their emotions or impulses, often in an aggressive or disruptive manner. The patient's behavior of skipping school, bullying, and smoking cigarettes may be a way for him to act out and express his emotions in response to the stress of his parents’ divorce. Projection involves attributing one's own unacceptable thoughts or feelings to someone else, passive aggression involves indirectly expressing anger or hostility, and regression involves reverting to an earlier stage of development. None of these defense mechanisms seem to fit the patient's behavior as well as acting out.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acting out is an immature defense mechanism in which a person engages in behavior that is unacceptable or socially inappropriate as a means of coping with stress or emotional conflict. The patient’s behavior of skipping school, bullying, and smoking can be seen as acting out in response to his parents' marital problems. Projection involves attributing one's own feelings or characteristics onto others, passive-aggression involves expressing anger indirectly, and regression involves reverting to an earlier, more primitive type of behavior. None of these defense mechanisms accurately describe the patient’s behavior.
